doc_id: Anonymous - 1793 - Memoir, on the sugar-trade of the British colonies_page_1.xml
text:
[17]
greater interests are sacrificed to the
less; and the progress of the British
Sugar colonies will not receive fair or
full play, nor can those colonies exert
the great vigour of which they may be
made capable, whilst this system is continued.
If it is necessary to the prosperity of
the Sugar colonies, that they should obtain
the plentiful and cheap supply of all
the articles their necessities require; it is
equally important to the progress of that
prosperity, and to the general commerce
of the kingdom, that the free and unrestrained
passage be preserved for Sugar,
their staple product, through the medium
of the British markets, in the raw
and refined state, to the continent of
Europe.
By the act passed in the last session of
Parliament,
